questions.text:
A 56-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of black, tarry stools and lightheadedness for two days. He has a history of cirrhosis due to chronic alcohol use. Temperature is 37ºC (98.6°F), heart rate is 116/min, blood pressure is 96/42 mmHg, respiratory rate is 20/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. The patient appears pale and fatigued but is oriented to person, place, and time. Physical examination reveals a distended abdomen with a positive fluid wave. Rectal examination reveals guaiac positive dark, tarry stool. Laboratory results are shown below. Intravenous access is established via two peripheral 18-gauge catheters. Which of the following is the best next step in management?  

 Laboratory value      Result     
 Hemoglobin      9.4 g/dL     
 Hematocrit      28 %     
 Leukocyte count      12,100 /mm3     
 Platelet count      88,000/mm3     
 PT/INR      25 seconds     
 PTT      28 seconds
questions.solution:
This patient presents with signs of hemorrhagic shock (tachycardia, hypotension, pallor, and lethargy), melena (i.e. black, tarry stool, guaiac positive stool), and anemia indicating gastrointestinal bleeding. Given the clinical history of cirrhosis the most likely source of bleeding is an upper gastrointestinal source. Gastrointestinal bleeding in patients with cirrhosis is often exacerbated by thrombocytopenia (platelet count less than 150,000/mm3), which is seen in this patient. The primary goal in acute management of a hemodynamically unstable patient who is actively bleeding is to restore and maintain perfusion of vital organs. The patient should receive immediate administration of IV fluids (normal saline or lactated Ringer's).        

Patients with cirrhosis and end stage liver disease can experience multiple hemostatic abnormalities that can lead to or exacerbate bleeding. Altered blood flow, thrombocytopenia, diminished functioning of platelets, and inflammatory alterations in endothelial cells can increase the risk of bleeding in this patient population. The cause of thrombocytopenia is often multifactorial in patients with chronic liver disease.    

Option Analysis

❌ Platelet transfusion :
Incorrect: While a platelet transfusion may be necessary to treat thrombocytopenia in patients who are actively bleeding, the immediate focus for this patient should be IV fluid resuscitation.  
✅ Intravenous fluid resuscitation  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Octreotide infusion :
Incorrect: Octreotide infusion serves as a part of the treatment for variceal bleeding. However, this patient should first be stabilized with intravenous fluids before being evaluated for variceal bleeding with an EGD.  
❌ CT angiography of abdomen/pelvis :
Incorrect: CT angiography of the abdomen/pelvis can be used for localizing the source of bleeding in patients who are hemodynamically stable without an obvious source of bleeding. This test would not be performed prior to stabilization with intravenous fluid resuscitation and EGD to look for the source of upper gastrointestinal bleeding.  
❌ Intravenous vitamin K :
Incorrect: Vitamin K should be considered when there is evidence of vitamin K deficiency affecting clotting parameters, which is likely in this patient with cirrhosis. However, this would follow immediate resuscitative efforts with intravenous fluids.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old man with a past medical history of coronary artery disease, hyperlipidemia, and hypertension is found to have acute right leg pain and swelling during morning rounds.  Five days ago, he was admitted to the hospital with community-acquired pneumonia and was intubated due to acute hypoxic respiratory failure. His medications during the admission included aspirin, atorvastatin, losartan, ceftriaxone, azithromycin, and subcutaneous heparin. He was extubated yesterday and transferred to the step-down unit. Vitals are within normal limits. Pulses are intact in bilateral lower extremities. On examination, there is swelling of the right calf with tenderness to palpation in the posterior calf. A Doppler ultrasound shows a deep vein thrombosis in the right popliteal vein. Laboratory studies from the morning are shown below. Which of the following studies should be performed next to confirm the most likely diagnosis?  

       Today      On admission (5 days ago)     
 Hemoglobin      10.6 g/dL      11.1 g/dL    
 Leukocyte count      8,500 /mm3      16,100 /mm3    
 Platelet count      78,000/mm3      278,000/mm3
questions.solution:
This patient who was hospitalized and treated for severe community acquired pneumonia is found to have a new deep venous thrombosis (DVT) and thrombocytopenia after being treated with subcutaneous heparin for DVT prophylaxis. He most likely has heparin induced thrombocytopenia (HIT) and should have platelet factor 4 antibody testing to confirm the diagnosis.          

The diagnostic workup for thrombocytopenia varies significantly based on the most likely underlying cause based on the clinical presentation and history. Initial evaluation typically involves a complete blood count (CBC) with a peripheral smear, which helps identify whether the thrombocytopenia is isolated or accompanied by other cytopenias. This may also reveal important clues like schistocytes in cases of microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (MAHA) or blasts suggestive of a bone marrow disorder.        

Further diagnostic tests may include coagulation profiles PT, aPTT, fibrinogen, and D-dimer level), especially when disorders like disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) are suspected, which presents with a combination of bleeding, clotting, and organ dysfunction. Coagulation profiles should be checked in cases of chronic liver disease. In patients with suspected thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP), tests for ADAMTS13 activity level and ADAMTS13 inhibitors are used to confirm the diagnosis. For suspected HUS, a stool sample should be sent for culture, Shiga toxin and complement testing. For suspected bone marrow pathologies, a bone marrow biopsy is essential to identify the nature of the marrow involvement (i.e. infiltration by malignant cells or fibrosis). In cases of heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT), platelet factor 4 antibody testing and platelet serotonin-release testing are used to confirm the diagnosis and guide appropriate management.  



Option Analysis

❌ ADAMTS13 activity level :
Incorrect: ADAMTS13 activity testing is not used for diagnosing heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT). It is used to diagnose thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP), where a deficiency of this enzyme leads to microvascular thrombosis and platelet consumption. This patient most likely has HIT from the use of subcutaneous heparin. 
✅ Platelet factor 4 antibody :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ D-dimer :
Incorrect: A D-dimer test is typically used to rule out thrombosis when clinical suspicion is low. Given that a DVT has already been confirmed via ultrasound, this test would not contribute any additional information. This patient has findings that are most consistent with HIT. 
❌ Bone marrow biopsy :
Incorrect: A bone marrow biopsy could help in the evaluation of thrombocytopenia where there is suspicion of bone marrow failure; infiltration by malignant cells; or other marrow pathologies, such as myelodysplastic syndrome or aplastic anemia. A bone marrow biopsy is not used to diagnose heparin-induced thrombocytopenia, which is the most likely diagnosis in this case.  
❌ Peripheral blood smear :
Incorrect: A peripheral blood smear would show thrombocytopenia in a patient with heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT), but it would not confirm the diagnosis. The presence of HIT antibodies directed against PF4 would confirm the diagnosis of HIT.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old woman comes to the emergency room due to an episode of bloody emesis. She was eating lunch when she felt nauseated and then vomited. The vomitus consisted of bright red blood mixed with partially digested food. Past medical history is notable for hypertension, type II diabetes mellitus, and atrial fibrillation. She is currently taking metformin, propranolol, and dabigatran. The patient drinks 1-2 glasses of wine in the evening. Temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F), pulse is 77/min, and blood pressure is 136/81 mmHg. Dried blood is seen around the patient’s mouth. Cardiovascular and pulmonary exams are noncontributory. An abdominal exam reveals mild epigastric tenderness but no distention or fluid wave. Laboratory testing is shown below. While in the emergency room, the patient has another episode of bloody emesis. Which interventions should be administered to this patient?  

Laboratory Value  
Results
Hemoglobin
13.0 g/dL  
Hematocrit
39%  
Partial Thromboplastin Time (activated)  
87 seconds  
Thrombin Time*  
96 seconds
questions.solution:
This patient has upper gastrointestinal bleeding in the setting of an elevated thrombin time (TT) and activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT). Her symptoms are due to a dabigatran overdose. Of note, dabigatran primarily prolongs TT and has a lesser effect on prothrombin time (PT) and aPTT.

Dabigatran is a direct thrombin inhibitor that can increase bleeding risk in the setting of overdose. Patients may experience uncontrollable internal bleeding from minor falls or trauma. Fortunately, a reversal agent called idarucizumab is available. It is an antibody that binds to and inactivates dabigatran molecules. For other direct thrombin inhibitors, there is no reversal agent available. Instead, tranexamic acid or prothrombin complex concentrate (PCC), which contains factors II, VII, IX, and XI proteins C and S, should be administered.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Idarucizumab:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Protamine sulfate:
Incorrect: Protamine sulfate is a positively charged molecule that can bind and inactivate negatively charged heparin molecules. However, protamine sulfate is ineffective in reversing the anticoagulant effects of dabigatran.  
❌ Octreotide:
Incorrect: Octreotide, a somatostatin analog, is used to treat acute variceal bleeding. Patients with variceal bleeding often have a history of heavy alcohol use and cirrhosis/portal hypertension (e.g., jaundice, ascites, engorged paraumbilical veins). In contrast, this patient lacks any such physical examination findings.  
❌ Fresh frozen plasma:
Incorrect: Fresh frozen plasma (FFP) can theoretically be administered to manage bleeding in patients with a dabigatran overdose. However, this approach is rarely used; idarucizumab is administered to bind and inactivate dabigatran molecules.  
❌ Aminocaproic acid:
Incorrect: Aminocaproic acid can be used to manage bleeding in individuals taking non-dabigatran direct thrombin inhibitors (e.g. bivalirudin). However, this patient has a dabigatran overdose, and idarucizumab is the first-line treatment option.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old man is brought to the emergency department for lower extremity swelling. His left thigh and knee began swelling after being tackled in a football game. He has not had similar symptoms in the past. Medical history is notable for hyperlipidemia and deep vein thrombosis. He has been prescribed simvastatin and apixaban. One week ago, the patient was diagnosed with bacterial prostatitis and started on ciprofloxacin. Temperature is 37.0 °C (98.6°F), pulse is 83/min, and blood pressure is 118/62 mmHg. Examination shows significant swelling of the left knee and thigh. The patient has pain with knee movement and limited range of motion. The thigh is tender to palpation. Sensation and pulse are intact in the lower extremities. Laboratory testing is shown below. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient?  

Laboratory Value  
Results
Hemoglobin
10.5 g/dL  
Hematocrit
31.5%  
Prothrombin Time  
40 seconds  
Partial Thromboplastin Time (activated)  
86 seconds

choices.text: Order mixing study on patient’s blood plasma
Perform genetic testing for JAK2 mutation

questions.solution:
This patient is taking apixaban, a direct factor Xa inhibition, but was recently started on a fluoroquinolone to treat bacterial prostatitis. The latter medication inhibits cytochrome P450 and increases plasma apixaban concentrations, resulting in internal bleeding in the left knee and thigh.

Andexanet alfa can be used as a reversal agent for factor Xa inhibitors. It acts as a modified human factor Xa decoy that binds drug molecules, preventing them from interacting with the body’s factor Xa. In scenarios where andexanet alfa is unavailable, activated charcoal can be used instead. Activated charcoal adsorbs drugs in the gastrointestinal (GI) tract and reduces the amount of drugs available for absorption into the systemic circulation.  

Option Analysis

✅ Administration of andexanet alfa:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Order mixing study on patient’s blood plasma:
Incorrect: Mixing studies, which involve adding fresh normal plasma to a sample of the patient’s plasma, are used in the workup of hemophilia. However, it is unlikely this patient has hemophilia given individuals with the condition develop symptoms (e.g., hemarthrosis, epistaxis) early in life.  
❌ Preparation for immediate fasciotomy:
Incorrect: A fasciotomy can be used to manage compartment syndrome. This patient has swelling due to bleeding into the left knee and thigh. However, he does not have signs of compartment syndrome (e.g., paresthesia, pallor, weak pulses, extreme pain), and a fasciotomy would not be appropriate at the moment.  
❌ Initiation of idarucizumab treatment  :
Incorrect: Idarucizumab is used to reverse the effects of dabigatran's direct thrombin inhibitor. Idarucizumab is not useful in reversing the effects of other anticoagulants.  
❌ Perform genetic testing for JAK2 mutation:
Incorrect: Patients with essential thrombocythemia have a JAK2 mutation. In this condition, the body synthesizes large quantities of platelets. The individual is at risk for bleeding since these abnormal platelets are dysfunctional. Individuals with thrombocythemia can also develop splenomegaly, weight loss, fatigue, and anemia. In contrast, this patient lacks these symptoms.

questions.text:
A 36-year-old man presents to the hematology clinic after having experienced prolonged bleeding after a recent tooth extraction. He does not have a personal or family history of bleeding disorders. He has no significant past medical history. Current medications include acetaminophen as needed for back pain. The physical examination is unremarkable except for scattered ecchymoses on the upper and lower extremities bilaterally. Laboratory studies are shown below. Which of the following tests should be performed next as part of the evaluation for prolonged bleeding? 

 Laboratory value     Result    
 Serum chemistries         
 Hemoglobin     12.4 g/dL    
 Leukocyte count     12,100 /mm3    
 Platelet count     240,000/mm3    
 Prothrombin time (PT)     12 seconds    
 Activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT)     60 seconds
questions.solution:
This patient presents with prolonged bleeding after a dental procedure. He has a finding on laboratory testing of an isolated prolonged aPTT. A mixing study should be performed next to help determine the cause of the prolonged PTT and the bleeding.       

A mixing study involves mixing the patient's plasma with normal plasma in a 1:1 ratio and re-measuring the aPTT. If the aPTT normalizes, it indicates that the patient’s plasma was deficient in clotting factors which the added normal plasma has replaced, suggesting a clotting factor deficiency such as hemophilia A or B. On the other hand, if the aPTT remains prolonged after the mixing study, this indicates the presence of an inhibitor that is preventing clotting, which could be an acquired inhibitor such as a lupus anticoagulant or an antibody against a specific clotting factor.        

The results of the mixing study would then guide further testing. If the aPTT corrects, then testing specific factor assays should be the next step to identify the deficient factor. If the aPTT does not correct, then lupus anticoagulant and factor-specific inhibitors should be tested for next.    

Option Analysis

❌ Factor VIII inhibitor titer:
Incorrect: Factor VIII inhibitors can be seen in the setting of hemophilia A following exposure to factor VIII replacement therapy, or they can develop spontaneously in the setting of autoimmune disease, malignancy, pregnancy, and certain medications. A mixing study should be performed first to evaluate the prolonged aPTT in this patient; if a factor VIII inhibitor is present, the mixing study would demonstrate immediate correction of the prolonged aPTT.  
❌ Factor XI level:
Incorrect: Factor XI deficiency can result in a bleeding diathesis because factor XI is activated by thrombin. As part of the evaluation for a prolonged aPTT, a mixing study should be performed first; If the patient has factor XI deficiency, it would result in complete correction of the prolonged aPTT .  
✅ Mixing study:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Factor IX level:
Incorrect: A factor IX activity assay would be indicated if hemophilia B is suspected, but it is not the initial diagnostic test of choice for a prolonged aPTT level. A mixing study should be performed first to determine if the prolonged aPTT corrects, which would suggest a factor deficiency. If it does not correct, that would suggest the presence of an inhibitor. Further studies would be done based on results of the mixing study. 
❌ Factor XII level:
Incorrect: Factor XII deficiency is a rare autosomal-recessive condition in which homozygous patients have a markedly prolonged aPTT without a history of excessive bleeding or hemorrhage. A mixing study should be performed first for a prolonged aPTT. In a patient with factor XII deficiency, the prolonged aPTT would correct which should then be followed by measurement of factor XII levels.

questions.text:
A 37-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department for malaise, confusion, abdominal cramping, and nausea for the past 3 days. The patient's partner states that she has been confused for the past day, not knowing where she is. She has no significant past medical history and takes no medication. Temperature is 38.6 C (101.5 F) pulse is 99/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, blood pressure is 136/76 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On physical examination, the patient appears fatigued. She is awake but not oriented to time or place. Abdominal examination reveals generalized tenderness to palpation without rebound or guarding. A Mild purpuric rash is present on the extremities bilaterally. The rest of the neurologic examination is non-focal. The results of laboratory tests are shown below. Peripheral blood smear demonstrates schistocytes, coagulation profile is normal, and ADAMTS13 activity is significantly decreased with an inhibitor detected. Which of the following is the best next step in management? 

 CBC     Result   
 Hemoglobin     8.2 g/dL    
 Leukocyte count     14,100 /mm3    
 Platelet count     7,000/mm3    
 Creatinine     1.4
questions.solution:
This patient presents with several clinical findings concerning thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP) including fever, fatigue, malaise, abdominal discomfort, purpura, and confusion. Blood work is consistent with microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, and mild kidney injury lab. There is decreased activity of ADAMTS13 and the presence of an inhibitor confirming the diagnosis of TTP. 

The mainstay of treatment for TTP is urgent plasma exchange (PEX) with high-dose corticosteroids. Other treatments include splenectomy, cyclosporine, cyclophosphamide, vincristine, and rituximab. A newer agent, the monoclonal antibody caplacizumab, has shown good potential for the treatment of TTP. These are typically used as adjunctive agents given when first-line therapy (plasma exchange and corticosteroids) fails to lead to improvement.       

Option Analysis

✅ Plasma exchange and high-dose corticosteroids:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Eculizumab:
Incorrect: Eculizumab is a monoclonal antibody used to treat patients with atypical HUS, which is mediated by autoantibodies against complement factors. This patient has TTP, requiring treatment with plasma exchange and high-dose corticosteroids. 
❌ Intravenous immunoglobulin:
Incorrect: Intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) is often utilized in the treatment of idiopathic thrombocytopenia. It can occasionally be used as salvage therapy in TTP when all other treatments have failed to lead to improvement. 
❌ Desmopressin acetate (DDAVP) :
Incorrect: DDAVP or desmopressin, is used for the treatment of von Willebrand disease, but it is not used to treat TTP. While von Willebrand disease can lead to easy bruising/bleeding, it does not lead to microangiopathic hemolytic anemia and decreased activity of ADAMTS13.  
❌ Piperacillin-tazobactam:
Incorrect: While TTP can mimic sepsis or an infectious process, in this patient it is caused by autoantibodies against ADAMTS13 and plasma exchange with high-dose corticosteroids should be the first line treatment.

questions.text: A 43-year-old man presents to the emergency department due to bilateral leg swelling. Three days ago, the patient developed a dull, achy pain and swelling in both calves. The swelling and pain have continued to worsen. The patient has had three lower extremity, and one upper extremity deep vein thromboses in the past. He does not currently take any medication. The patient does not use alcohol or tobacco, and he works as a waiter in a local restaurant. Temperature is 37.3 ºC (99.1 ºF), pulse is 84/min, respiratory rate is 18/min and blood pressure is 141/86 mmHg. On physical examination, both legs are edematous with mild erythema and tenderness to palpation. Lower extremity venous ultrasound with Doppler shows bilateral deep vein thromboses below the knee. The patient is given a dose of subcutaneous enoxaparin. Bloodwork is subsequently obtained. Which of the following tests is most appropriate to perform as part of the workup?

choices.text: Protein C activity level in four months
Anticardiolipin antibody now and in three months, regardless of initial test results
Prothrombin activity level in four months

questions.solution:
This 43-year-old man with a history of multiple prior venous thromboses is diagnosed with bilateral lower extremity deep vein thromboses. Given his extensive history of thromboses, he should be tested for an underlying hypercoagulable disorder. Given the presence of the current clot and the dose of enoxaparin administered in the emergency department that will interfere with testing, this patient should wait before certain hypercoagulable testing is performed. Testing for Protein C activity level should be performed four weeks after completion of anticoagulation, which would be in 4 months (assuming 3 months of anticoagulation treatment).    

If a hypercoagulable disorder is suspected, patients should be tested for inherited hypercoagulable states, including mutations in factor V Leiden and prothrombin gene, and activity levels of protein C, protein S, and antithrombin. While genetic testing can be performed right away, functional assays will be inaccurate with acute thrombosis and current anticoagulation treatment. These studies (e.g., protein C and S) should be performed 4 weeks after completion of anticoagulation therapy. The patient should also be assessed for antiphospholipid antibodies, which include anti-cardiolipin, anti-beta-2-glycoprotein, and lupus anticoagulant. A positive antiphospholipid antibody result should be confirmed with a repeat test in 12 weeks.   

Option Analysis

✅ Protein C activity level in four months:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Prothrombin activity level now:
Incorrect: In patients with a suspected hypercoagulable disorder, testing for prothrombin G20210A gene mutation should be performed, but Prothrombin activity levels are not checked. 
❌ Anticardiolipin antibody now and in three months, regardless of initial test results:
Incorrect: An initial anticardiolipin antibody would be appropriate to check now as part of the hypercoagulable disorder workup. Antiphospholipid antibodies (anti-cardiolipin, anti-beta-2-glycoprotein, and lupus anticoagulant) should be repeated at 12 weeks only if they are positive on the initial screen. 
❌ Prothrombin activity level in four months:
Incorrect: In patients with suspected hypercoagulable disorders, testing for a prothrombin G20210A gene mutation should be performed, but Prothrombin activity levels are not checked. 
❌ Antinuclear antibody now:
Incorrect: Patients with antiphospholipid antibody syndrome may have an elevated ANA and can have associated SLE. However, testing for antiphospholipid antibody syndrome should be performed with anti-cardiolipin, anti-beta-2-glycoprotein, and lupus anticoagulant testing.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old woman presents to the clinic with complaints of easy bruising and frequent nosebleeds over the past several months, and she reports progressively worsening heavy menstrual periods. Her mother and maternal uncle have a history of spontaneous bleeding. She has no significant past medical history and takes no prescribed medications. She has been taking glucosamine supplements for joint pain from running and doesn't take any other supplements or medications. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals scattered ecchymoses over the bilateral upper extremities. There is no hepatosplenomegaly. Laboratory results are shown below. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s bleeding? 

 Laboratory Test Result     
 Hemoglobin 11.8 g/dL     
 White blood cell count 7,500 /µL     
 Platelets 140,000 /µL     
 Peripheral smear No schistocytes     
 Prothrombin time (PT) 12 seconds (normal 11-15 seconds)     
 Activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) 42 seconds (normal 25-40 seconds)     
 Fibrinogen 250 mg/dL     
 D-dimer 0.5 mg/L     
 Creatinine 1.0 mg/dL
questions.solution:
The patient presents with easy bruising, heavy menstrual bleeding (menorrhagia), and has a family history of spontaneous bleeding. Laboratory results show a slightly prolonged aPTT, with normal PT and mild thrombocytopenia. The most likely diagnosis in this patient is von Willebrand disease.

Von Willebrand disease (vWD) is the most common hereditary bleeding disorder. It is caused by the qualitative or quantitative deficiency of the pro-von Willebrand factor which helps maintain levels of factor VIII and helps with platelet adhesion and binding to endothelial components after a vascular injury. Von Willebrand disease leads to a decrease in factor VIII levels (and often a slightly prolonged aPTT). Common manifestations include menorrhagia, bleeding after minor procedures, and mucocutaneous bleeding.    

Option Analysis

✅ Von Willebrand disease:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Hemophilia A carrier status:
Incorrect: Hemophilia A typically presents with deep tissue bleeding (hemarthroses or muscle hematoma), rather than mucocutaneous bleeding. Additionally, carriers do not exhibit symptoms unless they have extremely low factor VIII levels, which are unlikely given the normal PT and mildly elevated PTT. 
❌ Hemolytic uremic syndrome:
Incorrect: Hemolytic uremic syndrome typically occurs in children but can rarely be seen in adults. Patients present with thrombocytopenia, microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, and acute kidney injury. This patient has no evidence of microangioopathic hemolytic anemia or kidney injury.  
❌ Drug induced immune thrombocytopenia (DITP):
Incorrect: Drug induced thrombocytopenia (DITP) is thrombocytopenia due to drug-dependent platelet antibodies causing platelet destruction. Glucosamine supplements have not been associated with DITP, and this patient is not taking any other medications.  
❌ Disseminated intravascular coagulation:
Incorrect: Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) typically causes a prolonged PT and aPTT, low fibrinogen levels, elevated D-dimer, and evidence of both bleeding and thrombosis. This patient has a mildly prolonged aPTT, but lacks the other features characteristic of DIC.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man comes to the office for the evaluation of intermittent bleeding from gums and excessive bruising since childhood. The rest of the systemic review is unremarkable. Past medical history is noncontributory. Family history is significant for similar symptoms in the patient’s paternal grandmother, who required occasional blood transfusions. The patient does not take any medications or use illicit drugs. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows pinpoint bleeding from gums and multiple purpuras all over his body. A complete blood profile is unremarkable, and a peripheral blood smear shows normal morphology of platelets. Adding antibiotic ristocetin to the patient’s blood sample results in agglutination, but platelet aggregometry is abnormal. Genetic testing identifies a defect in the protein targeted by the drug, abciximab. Which of the following best describes the role of the protein inhibited by this drug in hemostasis?

choices.text: Binds fibrinogen and induce platelet aggregation
Binds platelets to von Willebrand factor on collagen
Facilitates the production of thromboxane A2 in platelets
Facilitates the conversion of plasminogen to plasmin

questions.solution:
This patient with mucocutaneous bleeding (bruising and gum bleeding), combined with an abnormal platelet aggregometry, is most likely suffering from Glanzmann thrombasthenia. This autosomal recessive disorder is characterized by defective or deficient glycoprotein IIb/IIIa on the platelet surface targeted by the drug abciximab.

Platelets play a significant role in primary hemostasis, defined by the formation of a platelet plug. It is divided into five steps:
  
  • Endothelial injury (step 1): It results in transient vasoconstriction via neural stimulation reflex and endothelin 
  • Exposure (step 2): von Willebrand factor (vWF) binds to exposed collagen 
  • Adhesion (step 3): Platelets bind vWF via the GpIb receptor at the site of injury only and undergo a conformational change, thereby releasing ADP, calcium ions (Ca 2+), and thromboxane A2 (TXA2). 
  • Activation (step 4): Released ADPs bind to P2Y12 receptor on platelets and induce GpIIb/IIIa expression at its surface 
  • Aggregation (step 5): Fibrinogen binds GpIIb/IIIa receptors and links platelets 
Primary hemostasis can be inhibited by antiplatelet drugs at different steps as described below:
 

Option Analysis

✅ Binds fibrinogen and induce platelet aggregation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Binds platelets to von Willebrand factor on collagen:
Incorrect: Glycoprotein Ib (GpIb) receptor on the surface of platelets binds to von Willebrand factor on the subendothelial collagen, facilitating platelet adhesion to the site of injury, where platelets undergo conformational changes. The deficiency of GpIb is seen in Bernard-Soulier syndrome and results in an abnormal ristocetin test (unlike this patient), and it is not targeted by abciximab.  
❌ Binds platelets to subendothelial collagen:
Incorrect: Glycoprotein Ia is responsible for binding platelets directly to the subendothelial collagen at the injury site. It is not inhibited by abciximab and does not result in abnormal platelet aggregometry.  
❌ Facilitates the production of thromboxane A2 in platelets:
Incorrect: Thromboxane A2 (TXA2) is produced by the action of cyclooxygenase (COX) on arachidonic acid which facilitates platelet aggregation. TXA2 production is inhibited by aspirin which blocks the COX enzyme.  
❌ Facilitates the conversion of plasminogen to plasmin:
Incorrect: Plasminogen is converted to plasmin by tissue plasminogen activator. This conversion is inhibited by antifibrinolytic drugs (e.g., aminocaproic acid and tranexamic acid), not by abciximab.

questions.text:
A 67-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of palpitations and dizziness. A diagnosis of atrial fibrillation is made, and the patient is started on warfarin for prophylaxis against future embolic events. Four days after initiating warfarin, she develops well-defined, purpuric, and bullous lesions over her thighs (see image below). Inhibition of which of the following components of the coagulation cascade is likely responsible for this woman’s lesions?  


Credit: Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This woman’s skin lesions in the setting of warfarin initiation are likely due to warfarin-induced skin necrosis as a result of the sudden depletion of protein C. Warfarin is an oral anticoagulant that interferes with the normal synthesis of vitamin K-dependent clotting factors (II, VII, IX, and X), and is used for both the treatment and prophylaxis of thromboembolic events. However, warfarin also inhibits proteins C and S, which are factors that function as anticoagulants (these proteins are thought of like the brakes on the coagulation cascade).  

Specifically, inhibition of protein C leads to a hypercoagulable state since it has the shortest half-life of all factors inhibited by warfarin. At therapeutic doses, the anticoagulant effects of warfarin outweigh the hypercoagulable ones, but protein C is depleted before the other factors during the initiation of the medication. This creates a temporarily hypercoagulable state during which the patient is more prone to clotting. This factor imbalance manifests in paradoxical pro-coagulation, resulting in microthrombules of blood vessels in the skin and subsequent purpura and necrosis. Warfarin-induced skin necrosis can be avoided by administering a heparin bridge when initiating warfarin therapy.  

Option Analysis

❌ Factor II:
Incorrect: This woman’s skin lesions are likely due to the paradoxical pro-coagulant effects following a decrease in protein C. Factor II is a pro-coagulation factor inhibited by warfarin.  
❌ Factor IX:
Incorrect: This woman’s skin necrosis following warfarin initiation is likely due to paradoxical pro-coagulation effects from decreased protein C. Although Factor IX is also inhibited by warfarin, it is a pro-coagulation factor.  
❌ Factor VII:
Incorrect: This woman’s condition results from necrosis due to the paradoxical pro-coagulation effects following the initial decrease in protein C after warfarin administration. Though Factor VII is also inhibited by warfarin, it is a pro-coagulation factor.   
✅ Protein C:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Protein S:
Incorrect: Necrotic skin lesions associated with warfarin administration result from the paradoxical pro-coagulation effects following a decrease in protein C. Protein S is another anti-coagulation factor inhibited by warfarin but has a shorter half-life when compared to protein C.

questions.text:
A 58-year-old man with a history of alcohol use disorder is admitted to the intensive care unit with a diagnosis of acute pancreatitis. On the third day of hospitalization, he has several episodes of hematemesis. Temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F), blood pressure is 85/50 mm Hg, heart rate is 124 /minute, respiratory rate is 20 /minute, and oxygen saturation is 95% on 2 L via nasal cannula. Physical examination reveals diffuse abdominal tenderness without rebound or guarding. Bleeding is noted at his peripheral IV sites. A comparison of laboratory results from this hospitalization is shown in the table below. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? 

 Laboratory Test     Admission Result     Day 3 Result    
 Hemoglobin     11.1 g/dL     7.5 g/dL    
 Platelet count     200,000 /µL     45,000 /µL    
 Prothrombin time (PT)     12 seconds     22 seconds    
 Partial thromboplastin time (aPTT)     30 seconds     60 seconds    
 Fibrinogen     N/A     120 mg/dL    
 D-dimer     N/A     5 µg/mL
questions.solution:
This patient has developed disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), as evidenced by acute thrombocytopenia, prolonged PT and aPTT, low fibrinogen, and elevated d-dimer. This case is complicated by acute gastrointestinal hemorrhage and resultant hemodynamic instability. The most important next step is to stabilize the patient’s anemia, thrombocytopenia, and coagulopathy with blood product transfusion. 

DIC is characterized by widespread activation of the coagulation cascade, leading to the formation of blood clots, often in the microvasculature. This results in consumption of platelets and coagulation factors, which can lead to severe bleeding. DIC is often triggered by an underlying condition, such as sepsis, trauma, malignancy, or, in this case, severe acute pancreatitis. Patients may develop signs of thrombosis and/or bleeding (e.g., petechiae, ecchymoses, bleeding from invasive sites). 

Patients should undergo initial ABCDE assessment and stabilization, as necessary. The management of DIC primarily involves treating the underlying cause, such as administering antibiotics for sepsis or supportive care for severe acute pancreatitis. However, if life-threatening bleeding develops, it is crucial to stabilize the patient by correcting the coagulopathy and managing active bleeding. This often requires the transfusion of blood products, including packed red blood cells to address anemia, platelets to correct severe thrombocytopenia, and fresh frozen plasma or cryoprecipitate to replenish depleted clotting factors.    

Option Analysis

✅ Transfusion of blood products :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Intravenous vitamin K :
Incorrect: Vitamin K can help correct coagulopathy due to vitamin K deficiency; however, it is not immediately effective and is not the primary treatment in the acute setting of bleeding from disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC). 
❌ Gastroenterology consult :
Incorrect: While a gastroenterology consult may be necessary for ongoing management and evaluation of hematemesis, the priority is to stabilize the patient’s coagulopathy and manage active bleeding with blood product transfusion. 
❌ Heparin infusion :
Incorrect: Heparin is not indicated in the acute management of bleeding associated with DIC and would likely worsen the patient's bleeding. 
❌ Tranexamic acid :
Incorrect: Tranexamic acid is an antifibrinolytic agent used to control bleeding, but it is not appropriate to use in this patient since it is generally contraindicated in patients with disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man undergoing treatment for gastric cancer comes to the clinic for a routine follow-up appointment. He reports feeling well and denies bleeding, bruising, leg swelling, or pain. He has no personal or family history of venous thromboembolism (VTE) or arterial thrombosis. Vital signs and physical examination are unremarkable. Venous Doppler ultrasonography of the lower extremities is negative for deep vein thrombosis. His recent laboratory studies are shown below. His physician is considering prescribing enoxaparin. Which of the following is the best statement regarding use of enoxaparin in this patient? 
 
 Laboratory Test     Result   
 Hemoglobin     12.0 g/dL    
 Platelet count     110,000 /µL    
 Prothrombin time (PT)     15 seconds    
 Activated thromboplastin time (aPTT)     34 seconds    
 Fibrinogen     400 mg/dL    
 D-dimer     7.0 µg/mL    
 Creatinine     0.8 mg/dL

choices.text: No treatment is necessary given the lack of signs and symptoms of thrombosis.
Enoxaparin should be given to prevent potential thrombosis.
Enoxaparin should be given to treat acute disseminated intravascular coagulation in this patient.
Enoxaparin should not be given because it is contraindicated in patients with this level of thrombocytopenia.

questions.solution:
This patient has chronic disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), as evidenced by a mildly low platelet count, mild PT and aPTT prolongation, normal fibrinogen level, and a high d-dimer level. However, the patient demonstrates no signs, symptoms, or imaging findings to suggest venous thromboembolism or arterial thrombosis. Therefore, anticoagulation with enoxaparin is not necessary.

Chronic DIC is characterized by continuous, low-grade activation of the coagulation cascade, leading to a relative balance between thrombosis and fibrinolysis. The body can partially compensate for the ongoing coagulation, preventing the severe bleeding episodes seen in acute cases. Thrombosis is more prevalent than bleeding in the chronic form of DIC.

Treatment typically focuses on addressing the underlying condition, such as treating an associated malignancy. Supportive care may include transfusions of red blood cells, platelets, or fresh frozen plasma (FFP) to manage active bleeding, if necessary. Anticoagulation, such as with low-molecular-weight heparin, may be indicated in cases of venous thromboembolism or arterial thrombosis. Despite the risks for bleeding and thrombosis, prophylactic treatments, such as FFP to correct PT and aPTT or anticoagulation to prevent thrombosis, are not recommended except in specific circumstances (e.g., before invasive surgery).       

Option Analysis

✅ No treatment is necessary given the lack of signs and symptoms of thrombosis. :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Enoxaparin should be given to prevent potential thrombosis. :
Incorrect: Anticoagulation is not necessary in patients like this one with chronic disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) who are asymptomatic and have no evidence of thrombosis. 
❌ Enoxaparin should be given to treat acute disseminated intravascular coagulation in this patient. :
Incorrect: This patient’s laboratory studies are not consistent with acute disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC). Even still, anticoagulation would not be indicated without evidence of thrombosis. 
❌ Enoxaparin should be used to treat microvascular thrombosis. :
Incorrect: While microvascular thrombosis may be present, anticoagulation is not indicated unless there is clinical or imaging evidence of macrovascular thrombosis. Otherwise, chronic disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) is managed by addressing the underlying cause. 
❌ Enoxaparin should not be given because it is contraindicated in patients with this level of thrombocytopenia. :
Incorrect: Anticoagulation is not indicated in this patient due to the lack of evidence for macrovascular thromboembolism. Anticoagulation is not contraindicated in patients like this one with mild to moderate thrombocytopenia.

questions.text:
A 41-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for evaluation of fatigue and generalized malaise for the past 2-3 days. She also reports non-specific abdominal cramping and nausea. Before this, the patient was in her usual health. She has no significant past medical history. Temperature is 38 (100.4) pulse is 104/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. The patient appears fatigued. Abdominal examination reveals mild generalized tenderness to palpation without rebound or guarding. Cardiac and pulmonary examinations are within normal limits. Blood work is obtained with results shown below. Peripheral blood smear shows schistocytes. ADAMTS13 activity level is significantly decreased, and an inhibitor is detected. Given the most likely diagnosis, which of the following additional features is most likely to be seen? 

 CBC     Result    
 Hemoglobin     7.9 g/dL    
 Mean corpuscular volume     80 fL    
 Leukocyte count     16,100 /mm3    
 Platelet count     20,000/mm3     
 Creatinine     1.3 mg/dL    
 INR     1.2

choices.text: Subcapsular and intraparenchymal hematomas on liver ultrasound

questions.solution:
This patient presents with several findings that are concerning for thrombocytopenic thrombotic purpura (TTP), including fever, fatigue, malaise, abdominal discomfort, evidence of microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, and thrombocytopenia. The findings of significantly decreased activity of ADAMTS13 and the presence of an inhibitor, confirms the diagnosis of TTP. Neurologic symptoms such as confusion and headaches are often seen in patients with TTP.

Patients with thrombotic microangiopathies (e.g., TTP, HUS) can present with similar symptoms. These often include constitutional symptoms and findings such as fever and chills, weakness and fatigue, easy bruising or bleeding, and gastrointestinal symptoms. Physical examination can show pallor and a purpuric rash (e.g., petechiae and ecchymoses). Significant renal involvement is uncommon in TTP, while neurological signs and symptoms including headache, focal neurologic deficits, seizures, confusion, and vertigo are often present.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Headache and confusion:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Vesicular rash:
Incorrect: A vesicular rash in a dermatomal pattern is suggestive of zoster. The rash associated with TTP is typically a mild purpuric rash. 
❌ Subcapsular and intraparenchymal hematomas on liver ultrasound:
Incorrect: These are common findings seen on ultrasound in patients with HELLP syndrome. They are not seen in TTP. 
❌ Hypertension:
Incorrect: Hypertension is not typically associated with TTP. It is typically seen with HELLP syndrome, defined as hemolysis, elevated liver enzymes, and low platelets in pregnant patients. 
❌ Splinter hemorrhages:
Incorrect: Splinter hemorrhages, a new cardiac murmur, petechiae, and thrombocytopenia can be seen in patients with bacterial infective endocarditis. However, the presence of significantly decreased ADAMTS13 activity confirms the diagnosis of TTP.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) presents to the primary care clinic to establish care. She has not seen a physician in many years and does not currently take any medication. The patient has had no recent chest pain, shortness of breath, abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, constipation, leg swelling, or unintentional weight loss. Vital signs are unremarkable. On physical exam, the patient is well-appearing, and cardiopulmonary auscultation is normal. The patient recently learned about the association of SLE with a blood clotting syndrome and is worried she may have it. Which of the following historical elements would most strongly indicate this syndrome?

choices.text: Personal history of middle cerebral artery thrombosis
Personal history of a spontaneous abortion at 9 weeks gestation
Personal history of right lower extremity venous thrombosis following knee surgery
Personal history of a prior pregnancy complicated by gestational hypertension
Family history of deep venous thrombosis in her mother who has pancreatic cancer

questions.solution:
This 26-year-old woman with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) presents to the clinic to establish care and inquiries about testing for a hypercoagulable disorder associated with SLE: namely, antiphospholipid syndrome. While serum testing is required to definitively make the diagnosis, a history of SLE and an unexplained arterial thrombosis (e.g., prior stroke in an otherwise young, healthy patient) or history of pregnancy complications (i.e., recurrent fetal losses or preeclampsia) would be concerning for the condition. If this patient had a personal history of middle cerebral artery thrombosis, it would raise suspicion for antiphospholipid antibody syndrome requiring screening, especially in a patient with SLE.        

Hypercoagulable (or thrombophilic) disorders are conditions that lead to an increased tendency to form blood clots. They can be inherited (e.g., factor V Leiden, prothrombin gene mutations, deficiencies of protein C, S, and antithrombin) or acquired, such as with antiphospholipid syndrome.        

All patients who present with thrombosis should be assessed for provoking risk factors, which include recent or temporary conditions that increase the risk of clotting. These may include recent surgery or immobilization, active malignancy, or active pregnancy. If no provoking risk factors are present, and the patient is < 45 years of age, has recurrent thromboses, or has thromboses in multiple veins and/or unusual sites; they should be screened for a hypercoagulable disorder. While the inherited thrombophilic disorders listed above generally cause venous thrombosis, antiphospholipid syndrome can lead to arterial and venous thrombosis and should be considered in any patient with unexplained arterial thrombosis.   

Option Analysis

✅ Personal history of middle cerebral artery thrombosis:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Personal history of a spontaneous abortion at 9 weeks gestation:
Incorrect: Recurrent (three or more) spontaneous abortions before 10 weeks of gestation is suggestive of antiphospholipid syndrome in the appropriate clinical setting. One spontaneous abortion at 9 weeks gestation typically does not raise suspicion for antiphospholipid syndrome. 
❌ Personal history of right lower extremity venous thrombosis following knee surgery:
Incorrect: Unprovoked venous thromboembolism in an otherwise young and healthy patient would be concerning for a hypercoagulable disorder. However, a provoked venous thrombosis would not be as concerning for antiphospholipid syndrome. 
❌ Personal history of a prior pregnancy complicated by gestational hypertension:
Incorrect: A history of adverse outcomes related to pregnancy that are associated with severe preeclampsia or placental insufficiency would be concerning for antiphospholipid antibody syndrome. However, gestational hypertension without these complications is less indicative. 
❌ Family history of deep venous thrombosis in her mother who has pancreatic cancer:
Incorrect: A family history of recurrent venous thromboembolism would be concerning for an inherited hypercoagulable disorder. However, family history of a deep venous thrombosis in the setting of malignancy would not be as concerning for antiphospholipid antibody syndrome.
